sub_topic: Schwarz reflection principle and its applications
message_1: Let's say you are given two holomorphic functions $f(z)$ and $g(z)$ in the open upper half plane $\mathbb{H}$, where $f(z)$ extends continuously to the real axis, and $g(z)$ extends continuously to the real axis, and is real-valued there. Assume that $f(z) = g(z)$ for all $z$ on the real axis. If $f(z) - g(z)$ is bounded in $\mathbb{H}$, then prove that $f(z) = g(\bar{z})$ for all $z \in \mathbb{H}$.
message_2:
To prove that $f(z) = g(\bar{z})$ for all $z \in \mathbb{H}$, we will use the Schwarz reflection principle.

First, let's define a new function $h(z) = f(z) - g(z)$. Since $f(z)$ and $g(z)$ are holomorphic in $\mathbb{H}$, $h(z)$ is also holomorphic in $\mathbb{H}$. Moreover, we are given that $h(z)$ is bounded in $\mathbb{H}$.

Now, let's consider the function $h(\bar{z})$. Since $h(z)$ is holomorphic in $\mathbb{H}$, $h(\bar{z})$ is holomorphic in the lower half-plane $\mathbb{L}$. Furthermore, we have $h(\bar{z}) = f(\bar{z}) - g(\bar{z})$.

We are given that $f(z) = g(z)$ for all $z$ on the real axis. Therefore, $h(z) = 0$ for all $z$ on the real axis. Since $h(z)$ is continuous on the real axis, we have $h(\bar{z}) = 0$ for all $z$ on the real axis as well.

Now, let's define a new function $H(z)$ as follows:

$$
H(z) = \begin{cases}
h(z) & \text{if } z \in \mathbb{H} \\
0 & \text{if } z \in \mathbb{R} \\
h(\bar{z}) & \text{if } z \in \mathbb{L}
\end{cases}
$$

$H(z)$ is holomorphic in $\mathbb{H}$ and $\mathbb{L}$, and continuous on the real axis. By the Schwarz reflection principle, $H(z)$ is holomorphic on the whole complex plane $\mathbb{C}$.

Since $H(z)$ is holomorphic and bounded in $\mathbb{H}$, by the Riemann extension theorem, $H(z)$ is constant. Since $H(z) = 0$ for all $z$ on the real axis, we have $H(z) = 0$ for all $z \in \mathbb{C}$.

Now, for all $z \in \mathbb{H}$, we have $h(z) = H(z) = 0$, which implies $f(z) - g(z) = 0$, so $f(z) = g(z)$. For all $z \in \mathbb{L}$, we have $h(\bar{z}) = H(z) = 0$, which implies $f(\bar{z}) - g(\bar{z}) = 0$, so $f(\bar{z}) = g(\bar{z})$. Therefore, we have $f(z) = g(\bar{z})$ for all $z \in \mathbb{H}$.
